awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Arctic Sensitivity to Climate Perturbations and a Millenial Perspective on Current Warming Derived from Shrinking Ice Caps
awd_abstract_narration: The goal of this proposal is to provide a millennial context for current warming and to better constrain the nature of abrupt climate changes over the past 5000 years in the North Atlantic sector of the Arctic. This goal will be addressed with the powerful datasets derived from radiocarbon-dated vegetation preserved beneath ice caps for centuries to millennia, but now being exposed annually by current ice-margin retreat across northeastern Canada and West Greenland. These chronologies define the pattern and timing of abrupt summer coolings in the recent past and place current warming in a millennial context. 14C dating of vegetation will be complemented by measuring in situ 14C inventories in recently exposed rock surfaces, providing essential temporal constraints on the duration of ice-covered and ice-free conditions throughout the Holocene. Combined, these two datasets will provide the most secure evidence for the character of current summer warming by explicitly dating when the region was last as warm as present. Comparing our climate reconstructions with on-going studies in NW Europe will help to separate the roles of unforced variability from hemispherically symmetric forcing as causes for abrupt climate change.  Research activities under this award will be made accessible to indigenous peoples by translating the goals and eventual results into Inuktitut, through posters that describe the research, and by offering public lectures in Iqaluit, the capital of Nunavut, and at Qikiqtarjuaq, where INSTAAR has long had a presence. This research program will train a PhD and MSc student, and provides opportunities for undergraduate students to become involved with research, building on successful traditions from previous years.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Thermometers document global warming over the past century, with Arctic warming twice as fast as the planetary average. But the instrumental record is too short to evaluate how "unusual" is the modern warming. Arctic glacier mass balances are determined almost exclusively by summer temperature, so changes in their dimensions provide one of the most reliable proxies for decadally averaged summer temperatures. The goal of this project was to provide a longer-term perspective on contemporary warming than is possible from the instrumental records by capitalizing on the radiocarbon ages of tundra plants entombed beneath glacier ice but now being exposed by widespread ice recession. The radiocarbon ages on entombed plants document when the region was last as warm as present, information that places contemporary summer warming in a millennia perspective. Over three field seasons we collected in situ tundra plants <1 meter from the ice margin from >300 unique ice caps; 245 of these samples were dated by radiocarbon. Of these dates, ~190 were <5000 years old, another ~10 were ~9000 years old, and unexpectedly, 48 of the samples from 30 unique ice caps had ages more than 40,000 years, indicating summers are now warmer than any century in at least 40,000 years. Because the plant ages were unexpectedly old, we utilized a second method to validate those ages. We sampled rocks adjacent to plants with old dates at 9 different ice caps and measured the amount of radiocarbon in quartz grains in those rocks. When rocks are exposed at Earth's surface radiocarbon is created by cosmic rays that break apart oxygen atoms in quartz, creating the radioactive isotope of carbon,14C. If the ice caps were continuously present over each site for more than 40,000 years, as the plant dates indicate, there should be almost no radiocarbon in those rock surfaces because radiocarbon has a half-life of only 5700 years. The measured radiocarbon in the rock samples was so low in all but two of the rocks sampled that these data confirmed the plant ages, and modeling indicates that continuous thin ice cover was plausible for all nine sites.  Collectively, these results demonstrate that the average summer temperature of the recent century exceeds any century in at least 40,000 years, including the early Holocene (about 11,000 years ago) when summer solar radiation in the Arctic was 9% higher than present because Earth's irregular orbit resulted in Earth being closest to the Sun then during Northern Hemisphere summer.  We are currently about as far from the Sun in Northern Hemisphere summer as Earth's orbit allows.  If the Sun's energy is the dominant control on glacier size, glaciers should be on average expanding, not retreating rapidly.

Because the radiocarbon clock runs out at about 40,000 years, our plant ages might be older.  To estimate the true age of the entombed plants we use ice core records from nearby Greenland.  The ice cores indicate summer temperatures were plausibly as warm as present during the last interglaciation, ~120,000 years ago, when Earth's orbital variables aligned to produce 12% more energy from the Sun in Northern Hemisphere summer.  We suggest that the true ages of our oldest entombed plants are about 120,000 years. Our findings add additional evidence to the growing consensus that the anthropogenic additions of greenhouse gases to the atmosphere coupled with strong positive feedbacks inherent to the Arctic have produced Arctic summer warmth exceeding that of any century in at least 40,000 years and very likely in 120,000 years.  

By quantifying the unprecedented nature of contemporary Arctic warmth our results capture the interest of climate scientists everywhere, but will also provide key unambiguous results to inform the wider debate surrounding the notion that contemporary ice loss is not unique (i.e., it is due to natural variability), and the potential role of human activity in causing ice loss. In doing so, these data provide a more secure context to evaluate likely future changes in sea level from the slower responding Greenland Ice Sheet. Improved estimates of changes in sea level over the next century are an international goal. This award supported the PhD thesis of Simon Pendleton (PhD expected 2018), and provided opportunities for undergraduate students to become involved with research. Miller teaches undergraduate courses for general education students (GEOL 1060 "Global Change" and GEOL 3040 "Climates of the Past") in which he incorporates the results of this and other research he has been involved with that provide "case studies" to illustrate primary scientific principles to a general audience. Student responses to course evaluation questionnaires routinely rate the case studies as the most effective means of understanding how scientific understanding of Earth history is created.
